reviewText:
Distraint is a short psychological horror title in which you play the role of Price, a young man whose job is to seize the property of others. He quickly discovers that he's entering a decent paying career at the cost of his own humanity.

The game is full of hidden meanings (even Price's name), and the story is something that almost everyone who has had a job can relate to. Myself personally being a slave to call center careers for the past decade, I certainly know how the protagonist feels and the story really hits home for me.

The graphics and gameplay style will easily remind players of titles such as Lone Survivor, Claire and Home. However, Distraint has a personality and concept that is unique to itself. The atmosphere in the game is heavy, brought on by dimly lit corridors and a pressurized ambiance that gives an overflowing sense of dread for the entirety of the game.

Distraint is an outstanding indie horror title that does its job of instilling fear and dread into the player. The puzzles are very easy and the game is very short, your initial playthrough may take anywhere from 1-2 hours to complete. Subsequent playthroughs will see 30-45 minute timeframes. There are a few grammatical errors within the dialogue at times, but the game is bug and crash free.

Though you may find yourself hard up to pay the asking price for such a short game, the price is worth every penny as every second is enjoyable here. It's also impressive that one person created this title in a little less than 3 months; the same creator behind Silence of the Sleep. If you're looking for a good horror title to spend some time with this Halloween, look no further.

Rating:  4.5/5.0 - Excellent, highly worth playing.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)

reviewText:
Distraint is psychological horror adventure game with very powerful moments of sadness and terror. I can say with confidence that this is one of the best games I've played in a long time.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:You play as a property-seizer called Price who is (to some degree) forced to seize people's houses in order to get a job. The game makes you to go to three different people, to which you have to explain that they're gonna have to leave the property. You have to help some of them in order to gain their cooperation. But even if they're willing to cooperate, Price's consciousness tells him that something is wrong with what he's doing. His mind soon becomes divided between getting the job and doing the right thing. That's when the crazy stuff begin to happen. Blood from everywhere, illusions, you name it. It's a perfect psychological horror.

Pros:    Amazing Atmosphere | This is the main component of every horror game. I have to say that this game is simply one of the best at creating such atmosphere. There are barely any jumpscares, but the whole feeling is made by music, art style, the story and the feelings that are caused by the story. The atmosphere is actually so good that I got goosebumps even while playing in the daylight!
Art style | This game's pixel art looks just amazing. If screenshot look at least slightly appealing to you, wait till you see it in action (you can just watch the video above!). The colour mix is really well-picked. I especially liked the purple-themed boss scene.
The Story | So, Distraint really has a story that touches one's heart. You have to take an old lady's home, visit her graveyard and face your inner dæmons. The story is always kind of unsettling and sad, but it also serves some (surprisingly) well-placed jokes that make you laugh while not losing the tense atmosphere.
The Music | As you might expect, the musical part of the game is really good as well. There are not many more things to say about it, though, except that it should have its own DLC.
Puzzles | There are a few (not many) puzzles in this game. They are a neat addition and they are quite enjoyable.
Achievements | There are 16 achievements in this game. They are mostly related to the story, but to unlock some of them, you will have to use certain items on certain objects or people. Or just do certain things. You will unlock most of the achievements on your first playthrough (2 - 3 hours), maybe even all of them, but to get the rest of them, you will have to play the game again. This is far from problematic, though, I completed the game several times and enjoyed the ♥♥♥♥ out of it. There is also a helpful guide on Steam Hub for this game, in case you'll get stuck somewhere.
Steam Integration | Apart from already mentioned Achievements, you will also get three Trading Cards for playing Distraint. Oh, yeah, and the backgrounds for crafting the badge look quite cool.
Cons:    SteamOS and MacOS Support | There isn't any. I don't know why, to be honest. It's a shame. Modern games should all support those two operating systems besides Windows.
Cloud Support | This game also doesn't have Steam Cloud support, but I don't find it too problematic since nothing except options is actually worth saving. The story is not too long, so even if you lose it, it's not a big problem. And it's worth replaying anyway.
Pricing | This is the first time I'm doing this so it might be a bit weird: I think $4,99 is not a high enough price for this game. The artistic value is amazing and it deserves more money.
The final verdict:This game is so good. I played the whole story multiple times and I enjoyed it every time. It has great thrilling moments, sad emotional moments, moments of wonder, jokes ... you name it. I confess, psychological thrillers are my kind of games an this one was no exception. While playing Distraint, I felt very similar emotions to when I played The Park (another great game, but overpriced), except with a tiny bit less horror involved. For some reason, the way they picked just the right colours really stands out, as you can see on Steam Store screenshots. All of the involved sounds are also really good, you can even choose between different sounds of text-switching. The default controls are a bit clunky, but you can set them to whatever you like, so that is not even remotely a problem.
If you like horror games, but not the ones with cheap jumpscares for little kids, this is probably a game for you. There are some similar games out there that should give you a pretty good idea what to expect. The games is definitely cheap for what it offers, so consider getting it. But if you see it on discount, click on that shiny green Add to cart" button without hesitation.

reviewText:
Ain’t Isn’t a Word, but DISTRAINT is a good game!Click for Full Review[gonewiththewin.com]

A good solid story is at the heart of DISTRAINT, don't be fooled by the simplified graphics, easy control scheme, and minimal inventory system. This game is a surreal spiraling descent into the maddening mind of Price, as his sins soon overpower him. Past sins interrupt and cloud the present, and the bizarre and grotesque becomes intermingled into Price's daily life. Very well done game and a great follow up to Silence of the Sleep.

What we liked:
- Surreal imagery.
- Disturbing sequences jolt you out of normal puzzle solving moments
- Atmospheric, spine tingling sounds, entice you and set the mood perfectly

What may through you off about this game is the retro graphics, simple design, and its middling degree of difficulty. I found that DISTRAINT's style was quaint and charming. More diversity, and length would always go a long way with gamers as well. Still, this is a wonderful little thriller, hard to put down once you sit down to play it!

reviewText:
You control Price, a man that has just started working as a repo man for the McDade, Bruton & Moore firm: you are their face when people need to be convinced of letting go of their property, you're the one doing the dirty part of the job and Distraint asks you how much of your humanity you're willing to let go to be successful.
You'll be playing through three different distraints plus a few more sections, exploring rooms, gathering objects and using them to solve simple puzzles: Distraint's gameplay might be pretty straightforward but is backed up by a very good story and great atmosphere.

PROS:

-the 2d pixel graphics are simple but feature a great style made up mostly through the smart use of black and white with a few contrasting colours in between

-really nice sound design and great soundtrack

-the art, sound and music all contribute to a greatly eerie and disturbing atmosphere where reality is interrupted by gruesome visions

-a quite good story and narrative dealing with morality and the consequences of one's decisions

NEUTRAL:

-the puzzles are, for the most part, very easy and straightforward, so don't expect much of a challenge

-the bobblehead-like faces might not be everyone's cup of tea and they're a bit lacking in expressiveness

CONS:

-the layout and timed puzzles of the third restraint can easily get confusing and leave you a bit stumped

-quite short, expect around 1,5/2 hours

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=567518969

I really, really enjoyed my time with Distraint even though its gameplay might be basic, most of the puzzles were a breeze and its linearity means there's little replay value unless you're achievement hunting. But the game's story and narrative are really good and can easily keep you engaged as you go through different distraints and see how Price reacts to what he has to do. The visions that sometimes break up reality not only serve as a great way to express Price's feelings but are also appropriately creepy, gruesome and serve as an important part of the plot.

When you consider that Distraint was an one-man project completed in just a few months I can only congratulate the dev on the result: Distraint is an effective and engaging psychological horror and an easy recommendation.

reviewText: An emotional, thought-provoking and brutally honest piece. From its unnerving horror, which keeps you at the edge of your seat to its rich characters, 'DISTRAINT' is an unforgettable look into the best and worst of people, and what we do to ourselves and one another.\n\nWhere so much of indie horror fails with boring design, broken gameplay, bad storytelling or a combination of those, 'DISTRAINT' is a breath of fresh air for the genre. This is what happens when game design, narrative and atmosphere are done well and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Well... After reading all of the good reviews for this game I decided to buy it, it was a huge sale anyway, so, why not. Andd... I can't say I regret I've bought and played it, but it leaves a huge depressing trace after finishing it, even though it doesn't lack some good humour.

The game itself is amazing, atmosphere, style, jokes, ironic commentaries, puzzles (spent a good hour on mushrooms level lol). I don't like horror games, but here wasn't much of it, so it was just a little bit creepy, especially playing at night with lights off.

Anyway, my point is.. This game must be played if you're 18-20 and older, otherwise you wouldn't understand what the game is trying to tell you.  The ending was pretty predictable, but nevertheless powerful. The moment with the lantern near Mrs. Goodwin's grave made me drop a tear.

9/10 for short, but amazing experience.

reviewText: Silence of the Sleep had terrific atmosphere but was ultimately unplayably broken in a second chapter that springs repeated deaths and forced reloads from a monster that randomly pops up and kills you over and over and over again while you're trying to work out obscure puzzles.  I spent a fair amount of time trying to power through Silence of the Sleep's chapter 2 but evetually gave up.  There was enough promise there that I wanted to see what Jesse Makkonen could do with better design decisions, though.  Distraint isn't quite there yet, but it's a step in the right direction.  Silence of the Sleep's art style would have made this better I think than the goofy looking bobble heads, the message of the game is pretty juvenile (the basic moral seems to be that deadbeats shouldn't have to pay their bills and only bad people would expect them to), and it's pretty short, but the atmosphere and gameplay are well done.

reviewText:
OverviewDistraint is a short but sweet, 2D psychological horror game, where you play as Price, an employee for a firm that takes houses back from people who can’t pay their debts. Over the course of the game, you come to some understanding about yourself, and realize just what is happening.

The atmosphere, dialogue, and read-between-the-line story makes it quite a unique title. There are many hidden meanings for you to find, the most obvious being the name of the character; Price, a man who seizes property because people are unable to meet their obligations.

ProsShort but sweet story, with very touching moments
Fun puzzles, and not too difficult to figure out which item to use on what
People have character, and you may genuinely feel bad for some of them
Music compliments the story perfectly
2D graphics with the grain filter work well together, and perfectly suit the atmosphere of the game
For achievement hunters: you can earn all of them on one playthroughConsDialogue is occasionally jerky with a few typos and some odd sentence structure (especially since the developer specifically thanks someone for proofreading in the credits)SummaryIt’s hard to find much wrong with Distraint. It looks good for what it was going for, the story is touching, the dialogue is moving, and people who work in similar fields can probably relate. It’s one of those games where being short works to its advantage. It’s well designed, ends just when it should, and is well worth your time and money. You can’t go wrong.

STORYYou are young guy, Mr. Price, who works for a big company which seizes properties and evicts people living in them, if they haven't paid their debts. When you see the consequences of your actions you start to have moral doubts. More and more you are willing to quit your job and to stop harm more people. But the greed wins, and you are still doing the same, lying to yourself that it is right thing to do. One day you have enough, you quit your job, start drinking and fall in debts. The only thing that left for you is to put shotgun in your mouth and pull the trigger.

reviewText:
DISTRAINT:
~~~~~~~~~

McDade, Bruton and Moore is a company that repossesses homes. Your name is Mr. Price and your first job is to tell an elderly lady she is going to have her house repossessed. How do you feel about it, Mr. Price? Any guilt, Mr. Price? Are you ready for more, Mr. Price? Because you have to make the hard decision, Mr. Price!

Distraint is an adventure / psychological horror game where you play Mr. Price, a repo man. This is truly an interesting game to say the least, as your character is going to do his duty all the while experiencing these sombre feelings called guilt and sadness for doing so. I really like the way these feelings are shown through the dark and dusty artworks. As you progress through the game, you will find objects in each location, helping you to advance through the story.

Realistically, these items are part of simple puzzles. Mr. Price goes through dark corridors armed with a lantern; he will discover properties step by step, which gives you the sensation of what is going to come next. Great stuff.

The atmosphere is sorrowful and suits Distraint perfectly. Visually, the game looks good and I really like the character’s animation. For me, Distraint has been well thought-out and everything you see and feel fits very well.

The controls are really easy to use as you will really need to use W,A, S, D for movements, E to use an item and SPC for your inventory.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great Artwork
-	Great atmosphere
-	Good Story
-	Achievement & trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Game is short

In Distraint, you will experience all sort of emotions and feelings. A very well executed game that deserves to be in your game library!

8.5/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText: It's a well-made and thoughtful game about the dark side of capitalism and the exchange of humanity for wealth. The story is pretty shocking and dark on most parts but there are quite some light hearted references and archivements to be found. reviewText:
There are a few restraining facts that should be known about Distraint before making a decision to invest time or money into the experience. First and foremost it’s a small game in every respect. It’s made by a one man team in a very short time and that show in everything from the length of the story and the assets used to the somewhat unpolished UI.

Mr. Makkonen is also Finnish and while obviously being quite fluid in his English there are some weird sentences and grammar not spotted in the proof reading. Sometimes it also feels like nuances in the dialogue has been lost in the translation.

With those reservations aside however I very much enjoyed the few hours it took to complete. The narrative feels fresh and the characters, while not overly complex, feels human enough to care for.
The story itself is about a man whose life choices doesn’t add up to his own moral compass, and the internal consequences of a life lived not true to oneself. The graphical horror could be said to represent his deteriorating self image, and the ending while quite obvious felt like a natural conclusion to the story.

Highly recommended for fans of Makkonens unique style and fans of psychological horror looking for something very different.

reviewText:
Odd game.
As a psychological horror game, it focuses more on the idea of horror and setting up scares before it uses jump scares to reset the tension.

The atmosphere is spot on and does an excellent job of setting the tone of the game.
The puzzles are more or less fetch quests, but the game is rather short so it doesn't detract from the experience.

It won't give you nightmares of any sort by using monsters or whatever, but it doesn't need to.
Its atmosphere is chilling and the imagery is frightening.
If you want a solid horror title that leaves you thinking about its message, then this is your game.
8/10

reviewText:
A game that begs the ever burning question; Would you sell your soul for money?

DISTRAINT: THE REVIEW!
A PERSONAL NOTE BEFORE THE GOOD BAD & UGLY!
This game was all what one would expect. linear, dark, depressing at times, surreal, while being very short. The trailer alone spoils the atmosphere that is constant within DISTRAINT. But don't let that turn you off! Through it's quirks, its got a charm that's not really seen in many horror games these days. And the price is not too shabby either!

HOWS THE GRAPHICS?
The graphics are pretty straightforward. 2D & Filtered. I will note that the art style they went for was kind of a turn off for me, it kind of took away from the horror aspect of it and just made it seem goofier than what it was trying to portray.

WHAT ABOUT THE STORY?
You play a liquidator for a loan firm on a one way trip to insanity, as he tries to cope with revoking his humanity for a livible wage. This go from bad to worse as the game progresses until things end in the darkest ways.

GAMEPLAY?
The gameplay is a rather well blend of Horror, Point & Click, and Puzzle! Even if it did some times dragged out in places.

SO WHATS THE COON'S VERDICT?

Pros:
Quirky game with a depressing but surreal plot
Good puzzles and gameplay that does envelop you in the story
Price is $4.99, if you got some pocket change to spare in that wallet
Cons:
Short
Lacking visual depth in its art style
Drags on in places
Final Score
7.5 OUT OF 10

And that ending? Just crazy, man. It doesn't offer too much in the way of replay value, but you get your five bucks worth on that first go. All in all, I do not regret buying this for a moment. It's probably one of the best games I've played in a while.

reviewText:
Short and Bittersweet, Distraint is a game that takes place in the life of Price. He's a debt collector who's rising up in the world and becoming more successful by the day, however after he takes away a home from a old widow he slowly slips into the realization that the human soul has a price and can be sold for success, to lose his humanity for a pay check. His mind slowly slipping into depression as reality distorts.

Roughly 2 hours, amazing art and sound track with dark humor and horror its a very nice experience which I would have loved to be longer, its only 5 bucks and feels worth every penny to support this man and his creations. Though I dont see this game going to far with the main audience on steam I can see it filling into a nice niche with some people. Its a realy good heartfelt story people shouldent miss.


If you liked this please check out Silence of the Sleep aswell, where the developer had put even more time and effort to create a real experince. Its a lot longer and much more complexe then this

http://store.steampowered.com/app/321870/

reviewText:
This is essentially a short story in game form (it took a bit less than two hours to complete). You are Price, a man who is trying to get into a banking firm. Throughout the game you must tell three people that they need to leave.

The writing is a bit too on the nose for my tastes- the themes are incredibly obvious beause of the dialogue. So while I could have used a bit more subtlety in the storytelling, the atmosphere makes up for it. It's really surreal, odd, and offbeat thanks to the unique super deformed visual style. I wouldn't call it pure horror, but it can definitely be creepy and unsettling.

I wouldn't buy this at full price, but if you can get it on sale, it's worth the purchase. It may only keep you busy for a night, but its visuals and atmosphere are weird enough that they'll stick with you even if the story isn't quite as subtle as it could be.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Distraint was... Interesting. If you are someone who struggles with your own inner demons due to choices you've made in your past, this game just may be for you.\n\nDo I recommend it? I've gone back and forth on that question for a minute now. Yes, I recommend it if you're looking for a short game that will make you question everything you've done in your own life. No, if you dont want to wonder if you've been a decent person.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Distraint was programed by one person over the course of a few months, but you would never guess it from playing the game. It is extremely well done, capturing its intended atmosphere perfectly. Despite being a shorter game it offers a rich and rewarding story that sticks with you. While not the scariest game to ever exist, it did make me jump a few times. There were also a few times where I found myself hesitating to proceed. Both of which are truly admirable feats in side-scrolling games.


Pros:
>Solid story that keeps you wanting more throughout the game.
>The style and feel of the game is distinct, well done, and matches the story perfectly.
>Teaches the player a valuable lesson in the form of a short story.
>Smooth gameplay, does not have any weird bugs or glitches at all, easy to stay immersed in the game.
>Steam achievements and controller support.

Cons:
>Does not save to the Steam cloud

reviewText:
Slight Thumbs up.... almost didn't recommend this one,

The fact that this game was made in 3 months is really impressive.
Graphics are really good.
Soundtrack is amazing.

but...
I got kinda bored playing this game...especially the second act.
Money is baaaaadd greed is baaaaad...the story to me was kinda cliché and overly dark.
I mean Price bosses are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s but if you can't pay your debts in life...sadly there are consequences.
Some people in other reviews said they cried and got really emotional not me...not really.
i'm not into the ''capitalism is bad'' bandwagon so yeah sometime i agreed with the bosses lol
And the ending... it was kinda clever but way WAYYY too dark for no reason. (imo)

Listed as a horror game but not really scary it's more of a dark/athmospheric story driven game with point and click style puzzles. You won't die in this game you don't have to hide from enemies or survive.

I recommend it cause it's cheap, i mean my sandwich that i bought from the store tonight cost me more than this game. Took me about 2.5 hours to finish

6/10 for me. Do not play this game if you are a depressed person lol.

reviewText: Take one Silent Hill loving game developer with no real knack for writing and no real understanding how psychological horror works. Give him quite good art and sound design skills. Don't explain to them how and why puzzles are done in story-driven games. You get Distraint. A game that desperatly tries to tell a psychological horror about guilt and EVIL CORPORATE SYSTEM that is so EVIL and INHUMANE using the most hamfisted SYMBOLISM and incredibly boring gameplay.\n\nThis is a purely story with puzzles" horror game (which has manual saves seemingly just because either developer couldn't figure out how to make autosaves work or just because the engine they chose is pretty bad at autosaving)
date: where you just walk back and forth small locations in 2D perspective trying to find the next trigger for the next thing to happen to procede to a next location and repeat the process ad nauseam. There little rhyme or reason to a lot of things that happen with game never really understanding that you can't mix totally unreal situatons with real situations without any thought and hope that it creates a surreal feeling instead of the mess you just don't care about.\n\n"Puzzles" are usually "guess what silly item combination you need to do" kind with several pointless minigames
recommended: including one that isn't a puzzle but a guessing game. There are countless moments when you just don't know what game wants from you
hoursPlayed: either because you need to revisit some place for no reason and some new interaction is now available
voteText: or because you need to use an item in some illogical way (often the former). Game constantly tries to bombard you with YEAH EDGY moments for no reason
votesTotal: drugs popping up and making you sigh and roll your eyes instead of feeling any kind of tension or surprise. It's just there. Evil people are EEEEEVIIIIL. Any attempts at some symbolism are silly at best.\n\nIt's a really really silly game that could've been fine if it was even shorter or went for a dark comedy twist. Instead
votesFunny: it's too long (for being around 2-3 hours game)
commentsCount: too messy and stupid and isn't worth your time. There are better examples of 2D horror adventure/survival horror like The Last Door
column19: even also TOO EDGY and silly The Cat Lady is more worth your time than this."

reviewText:
Meh. A super short (around 2 hours) psychological Horror game, or rather an interactive story in this case. Besides some Puzzles (which are basically just use this on that to get this to use on another thing). This goes on throughout the whole game. While the atmosphere is pretty neat, it always feels like there is nothing much to it, or downright there just for the shock factor. That main theme of the main characters Price is Guilt gets made pretty clear after even 5-10 minutes of the game.

I'm sorry, but as a huge fan of the Silent Hill series this game left me really underwhelmed, already not expecting much to begin with. Many sudden scary moments are very predictable or resort down to Blood, at times this felt exactly like reading your average videogame creepypasta.

Considering the lack of gameplay, the short lenght, the very easy puzzles, the predictable story and the rather lazy attempt at horror, i can't really recommend this game, even for it's cheap price, especially because there are way better alternatives out there for the same price.

reviewText: Dark, both literally and story-wise, but worth the price of admission. Distraint is one of those games that's worth playing once, maybe twice for achievement hunting (much like The Park). The art style is interesting, and brings with it a feel that another style wouldn't have. Some puzzles can be frustrating if you don't happen to go just the right way under just the right circumstances or click just the right thing that often feels arbitrary once you finally discover it, but there are Let's Plays on Youtube if you're really stuck and looking for a hint. The story is the real heart of this game.\n\nNot recommended for people who trigger easily, but then you're probably not looking for a horror game if that's the case.

reviewText:
Distraint is a very short horror-adventure about a man and his life choices.

I found the horror aspect to be lacking. The jump scares fell flat on their face for the most part due to poor execution and choice of graphics style. However, the game did fine with setting a creepy and unsettling atmosphere. I can think of one moment that was kind of gross.

The gameplay is very simple and doesn't require much from the player. You'll mostly be walking around and solving the occasional puzzle. Some of the puzzles can be confusing due to the mental state of the character which means that solutions might not appear logical in the normal way. You'll be doing some weird things. You might also become very stuck at certain parts like I did.

The strongest part of this game is the story which suffers slightly from subtle English errors in the form of missing words for some expressions and one idiom that is reversed. The story does have some good moments, especially towards the end of the game. One of them was touching and the other made me think, No way."

Overall
date: the game seems like an okay experience and made me want to finish it despite having some difficulties with a couple puzzles. The price point is really up to the person
recommended: but if you're on a tight budget and are looking for many hours per dollar spent
hoursPlayed: this game is clearly not going to live up to that expectation."

reviewText: I picked up Distraint hoping that it would be one of those little 16-bit-esque games with a killer soundtrack that helps carry the graphical style, and to some degree that's what I got, but not so much that it blew me away. The story is very unique, and I wonder now whether that uniqueness is part of what left me feeling like I was just grinding it out in the end, because I was never really emotionally invested in the protagonist's victims"? The horror was underdone
date: and I say that because Distraint starts off strong
recommended: but by about 2/3 of the way through it pretty much ceases to exist. In a lot of ways this makes it feel like you are playing two separate games - One that has the bones of a great shock-horror
hoursPlayed: and then later it is watered down to a semi-emotional scrolling sim with plenty of drug use. Likewise
voteText: the soundtrack starts off pretty well
helpfulPercent: and then just dulls down with the horror aspect of the gameplay.\nThe reason I can't be super harsh in my evaluation of this game however
votesHelpful: is that it was only a three month project start to finish. Yes it shows
votesTotal: and yes it is a little more frustrating than if the game was just completely rubbish the whole way through
votesFunny: but it is still pretty well on par for games around the $2-$3 mark even though they would have had far more time invested in most cases. Distraint is solid enough of a game that it asks the question of other games in its price range
commentsCount: "What did you actually deliver for all that time you spent?" And rightly so
column16: it's the question I'll be asking from now on too!\nGreat concept
column18: but it's a shame it was rushed."
